thread.title: Local Scene: Dark Star Orchestra guitarist joins theCAUSE for D-Jam
thread.title_full: Local Scene: Dark Star Orchestra guitarist joins theCAUSE for D-Jam

author: Scott Mervis / Pittsburgh Post-Gazette
title: Local Scene: Dark Star Orchestra guitarist joins theCAUSE for D-Jam
text:
Local Scene: Dark Star Orchestra guitarist joins theCAUSE for D-Jam March 16, 2017 12:00 AM Guitarist Jeff Mattson of Dark Star Orchestra By Scott Mervis / Pittsburgh Post-Gazette 
It will be a Deadhead’s dream Saturday at the Rex Theater for the annual D-Jam, benefiting the anti-hunger organization Just Harvest. 
Pittsburgh band theCAUSE, known for its deep Dead sets, will be joined once again by Jeff Mattson, of the Grateful Dead tribute band Dark Star Orchestra, as well as DSO vocalist Lisa Mackey. 
New to D-Jam will be WDVE Morning Show host and Ramble keyboardist Randy Baumann, joining theCAUSE members David Tauberg (bass), Eric Weingrad (guitar), Jill Simmons (vocals), Mike South (drums) and Bill Maruca (keyboards). 
“This is the fourth time Jeff has been a part of D-Jam and the first time for Randy, although he has jammed with the band on several occasions in the past,” Mr. Tauberg said in a statement. “We are looking forward to another evening of ‘GRATE’ music as we raise money for our friends at Just Harvest.” 
Over the past 18 years, D-Jam has raised more than $75,000 for local nonprofits. 
It begins at 8:30 p.m. Tickets for the 21-and-over event are $20 and can be purchased at the door or online at justharvest.org. ■ 
On a related note, The Deadphish Orchestra, a quartet from Colorado, couldn’t decide, so it will cover two generations of jam rock at once on April 13 at Jergels in Marshall. 
Tickets are $15 advance; $19 day of show at jergels.com ■ 
Pittsburgh bluesman and CAPA teacher Jimmy Adler toured France in 2012 with the Cash Box Kings, and now he’ll open for the old-school Chicago blues band at Moondog’s in Blawnox on Friday night. 
The Cash Box Kings, on Blind Pig Records, honor the Chess and Sun Records era, with Joe Nosek working in the spirit of Little Walter and Slim Harpo and Oscar Wilson in the vein of Muddy Waters. 
It begins at 8:30 p.m. Cover is $10; www.moondogs.us . ■ 
A few of our Pittsburgh acts went south for the weekend to play the SXSW Music Conference in Austin. 
Garage rockers Semi-Supervillains had played three shows already by Tuesday night and were set to play again at midnight Wednesday. 
Two of the gigs were at the Cheers Rooftop Bar in the heart of Downtown. “It’s a cliche Austin live music venue but it’s magical,” says frontman Vinnie Longhi. “Trees decorated in lights growing through the deck.” 
Soul-rock band The Commonheart is there Thursday and Friday (having played Nashville Tuesday) and return on March 23 for a sold-out homecoming show at Club Cafe.
